title: Morphlines is not resolving
description:
This version of morphlines does not resolve for me and Grant.

::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
::          UNRESOLVED DEPENDENCIES         ::
::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
:: org.kitesdk#kite-morphlines-saxon;0.11.0: not found
:: org.kitesdk#kite-morphlines-hadoop-sequencefile;0.11.0: not found



Has this been deleted from Cloudera's repositories or something? This would be pretty bad – maven repos should be immutable...

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
AFAICT, version 0.11.0 of those two artifacts are not available from the cloudera repositories - I can see 0.10.0, 0.10.0-* (several), and 0.12.0, but no 0.11.0: 

  http://repository.cloudera.com/cloudera/libs-release-local/org/kitesdk/kite-morphlines-hadoop-sequencefile/
  http://repository.cloudera.com/cloudera/libs-release-local/org/kitesdk/kite-morphlines-saxon/

  https://repository.cloudera.com/cloudera/repo/org/kitesdk/kite-morphlines-hadoop-sequencefile/
  https://repository.cloudera.com/cloudera/repo/org/kitesdk/kite-morphlines-saxon/

I made a tarball of all the 0.11.0 files under my ~/.ivy2/cache/org.kitesdk/ directory and put them here:

   http://people.apache.org/~sarowe/solr-dependencies-org.kitesdk-0.11.0.tar.bz2

comments.author: Robert Muir
comments.content:
Steve can we commit that to the default ivy-settings.xml for now?

We need to unbreak trunk.

comments.author: ASF subversion and git services
comments.content:
Commit 1576360 from Steve Rowe in branch 'dev/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1576360 ]

SOLR-5848: add reference to temporary morphlines 0.11.0 download site to lucene/ivy-settings.xml to allow 'ant resolve' to work

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
Steve can we commit that to the default ivy-settings.xml for now?

I don't know how to make ivy pull from a remote Ivy cache, so I instead put up the v0.11.0 org/kitesdk/ section of my ~/.m2/repository/ here: http://people.apache.org/~sarowe/.m2repo/ and modified lucene/ivy-settings.xml to pull from there.  After I deleted my ~/.ivy2/cache/, ant resolve succeeded for me, so it appears to work.

We need to unbreak trunk.

I've committed the lucene/ivy-settings.xml change to trunk.

I agree, but why not branch_4x too?  It's also affected.

comments.author: Robert Muir
comments.content: Thank you! Yes, i just figured trunk was most important so anyone trying to checkout the source code for the first time is able to get it working.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content: Hey guys, I'm getting this looked at.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
This should be resolved shortly.

Also, FYI, there is also ongoing work to push Kite to Maven Central.

comments.author: ASF subversion and git services
comments.content:
Commit 1576429 from Steve Rowe in branch 'dev/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1576429 ]

SOLR-5848: remove reference to temporary morphlines 0.11.0 download site from lucene/ivy-settings.xml - 'ant resolve' now works against the cloudera repos

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
This should be resolved shortly.

Thanks, Mark, I successfully ran ant resolve after removing the org.kitesdk/ dir from ~/.ivy2/cache/ without the temporary people.apache.org repository, so I reverted my commit enabling the temporary repository.

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
http://people.apache.org/~sarowe/solr-dependencies-org.kitesdk-0.11.0.tar.bz2
http://people.apache.org/~sarowe/.m2repo/ 

I'll leave those up for another 24 hours or so, then remove them.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
Thanks Steve.

Here is the CDK issue around moving Kite to Maven Central if anyone is interested in following:

https://issues.cloudera.org/browse/CDK-281

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
I looked at kite-morphlines-core-0.11.0.jar on both of the Cloudera repositories used by Ivy in the Lucene/Solr build:


<ibiblio name="cloudera" root="https://repository.cloudera.com/artifactory/repo" m2compatible="true" />
<ibiblio name="releases.cloudera.com" root="https://repository.cloudera.com/content/repositories/releases" m2compatible="true" />



Both of these repos contain the same jar, with checksum: d937428805e0e1e4e074769d732ea61293cbe5e8 

On trunk, solr/licenses/kite-morphlines-core-0.11.0.jar.sha1 contains: 6dfd4325dcd202e24104ff1eb604fcf4322b917c

Mark Miller, this seems bad, given that Maven repos are supposed to be immutable - do you think Cloudera will restore the former versions of the jars?  Or should Solr switch to the checksums for the new versions of the jars?

comments.author: wolfgang hoschek
comments.content: Going forward I'd recommend upgrading to version 0.12.0 rather than dealing with 0.11.0 because 0.12.0 is compatible and there are some nice performance improvements and a couple of new features - http://kitesdk.org/docs/current/release_notes.html

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
HI Wolfgang, 

We need a short-term solution to unbreak ant precommit: since it's an all-or-nothing target, once it fails, no further checks are run, so people can't/won't use it to find problems.

I'm not going to do the morphlines upgrade, since I don't know the code.

I'll commit the new 0.11.0 checksums shortly.  People will need to clear the org.kitesdk/ directory in their ~/.ivy2/cache/, and remove the old jars from their (test-)lib/ directories.

comments.author: wolfgang hoschek
comments.content: Sounds good. Thx!

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
Thanks Steve.

Let's update the checksums. I'll upgrade the version of Kite to 0.12 when I get some free time - probably tomorrow.

do you think Cloudera will restore the former versions of the jars?

I don't really know the details of what happened with that crash or what can be done about it, but I can ask about it.

Longer term, hopefully this type of thing is resolved by moving Kite to maven central.

SOLR-5848: update the checksums for the 0.11.0 morphlines jars

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content: I committed the updated checksums to trunk and branch_4x.

comments.author: Robert Muir
comments.content: Now checksums fail for anyone (including jenkins servers) who already downloaded these jars. Is there a clean way to expunge them without having to re-download the internet? it seems very very sketchy that these jars checksums changed to me.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
do you think Cloudera will restore the former versions of the jars?
I don't really know the details of what happened with that crash or what can be done about it, but I can ask about it.

I think Cloudera should really restore the old versions! I am not sure which version of morphlines shipped with Solr 4.7, but this makes the source tgz if dependent on that version no longer build correctly (ok, the JAR/WAR files are created correctly, but all validation tasks fail).

I think the Lucene Jenkins servers still has 4 copies of the JAR files (Policeman Linux, Policeman Windows, Policeman Mac, Apache Jenkins) from IVY and one copy of Maven (Apache Jenkins). If Cloudera wants to get them back, I can send them.

comments.author: Robert Muir
comments.content:
I did the following locally (hopefully not corrupting anything). We may need to do it on all jenkins servers too:


rmuir@beast:~/.ivy2/cache$ find . -name "*kite*" | xargs rm -rf
rmuir@beast:~/trunk$ ant clean clean-jars precommit

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
We may need to do it on all jenkins servers too:

I'm working on it on the Apache lucene Jenkins slave.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content: Uwe, can you attach the jars in case we can get them to do this?

comments.author: Robert Muir
comments.content:
Jenkins still wouldnt have all the data to reconstitute right? Don't maven artifacts typically have -source and -javadocs jars too?

These are used e.g. by IDEs.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
We are  discussing this internally. It doesn't look good 

More to come.

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
The Apache lucene Jenkins slave should be all set.  I did the following after running sudo su - hudson on lucene.zones.apache.org (the Lucene-Solr-Clover-4.x job is currently running, and the *-4.3* and *4.4* checkouts aren't affected):


$ rm -rf ~/.ivy2/cache/org.kitesdk
$ cd hudson-slave/workspace
$ shopt -s extglob
$ for a in !(Lucene-Solr-Clover-4.x|*4.[34]*) ; do echo $a ; cd $a ; if [ -f build.xml ] ; then echo running ant clean-jars ; ant clean-jars ; else echo not running ant clean-jars ; fi ; cd .. ; done
$ cd Lucene-Solr-Tests-4.x-Java7
$ export JAVA_HOME=/usr/local/openjdk7
$ export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH
$ JAVACMD=$JAVA_HOME/bin/java ant resolve
$ for a in $(find * -name '*morphlines*.jar'|grep -v /build/) ; do echo $a ; cp $a ../Lucene-Solr-Clover-4.x/$a ; done

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Steve Rowe: I cleaned up the ASF Jenkins workspaces, too. The outdated workspaces were deleted (Jenkins does not delete the workspace when the job is deleted, so the 4.3 and 4.4 ones were just relicts).

But in general: There is no need to clean up JAR files in workspaces after such events, because Jenkins is configured to start with an cleaned up workspace (means Jenkins deletes all non-svn files, which is like an svn revert, but a bit more). When a job starts the workspace is as clean as a new checkout.

The only thing you have to do: nuke ivy cache.

I did this for the Policeman servers: Windows Policeman and MacOSX Policeman were restored to latest VirtualBox snapshot with empty homedir, Linux Policeman got rm -rf ~jenkins/.ivy (I dont care about downloading the internet).

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content: I attached the Maven repository from ASF Jenkins (everything below ~/.m2/repository/org/kite). This machine runs Maven builds and so the directory already has the correct layout. The files there are the ones with the old sha1 (see also file date).

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
Steve Rowe: I cleaned up the ASF Jenkins workspaces, too. The outdated workspaces were deleted (Jenkins does not delete the workspace when the job is deleted, so the 4.3 and 4.4 ones were just relicts).

Cool, thanks.

But in general: There is no need to clean up JAR files in workspaces after such events, because Jenkins is configured to start with an cleaned up workspace (means Jenkins deletes all non-svn files, which is like an svn revert, but a bit more). When a job starts the workspace is as clean as a new checkout.

I thought that was true, but figured it wouldn't hurt to clean-jars.

comments.author: Steve Rowe
comments.content:
I attached the Maven repository from ASF Jenkins (everything below ~/.m2/repository/org/kite).

This is a typo - the groupId is org.kitesdk, not org.kite - I checked Uwe's attached tarball and it has the right stuff under org/kitesdk/.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
Good news it looks. Unfortunately, since Solr does not depend on all the kite or morphline jars, we wouldn't have all that we need to properly replace - but it looks like we actually do have a copy of all the original artifacts internally.

I still have to test them out, but no reason that shouldn't go well.

The bad news I suppose, is that it will cause some more commotion to return to them, but it would solve the problems with the 4.7 release.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content: Cool thanks. Drop a note before you commit of the revert of the sha1 files, so I can tell the Jenkins server's shell to nuke the Ivy cache.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
This is a typo

I missed to add a star *, because this is what I used to tar the stuff

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
They are going to flip back in 1-1.5 hours or so. I should have computer access no later than an hour or so after that. (Currently away from my machine). 

Sorry if the timing ends up being a little inconvenient. A few factors in play today.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Hi, unfortunately I have to go to bed. I brought Policeman Jenkins into "shutdown mode", so it runs no new builds until i stop the shutdown mode. I hope the new sha1's are committed until tomorrow.
If somebody else could take care of nuking ASF Jenkins' Ivy cache, I would be happy.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content: Thanks Uwe.

comments.content:
Hi,
done! For ASF Jenkins. I will restart Policeman now.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Mark Miller: You recent commit added back some outdated JAR checksums from unrelated files. Before doing a checksum recalculation, you should first delete all JAR files that already exist in the checkout's lib folders: ant clean-jars.

I fixed this before Jenkins complains.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content: Any reason that's not done by default for the checksum target?

comments.author: Steven Bower
comments.content: Just grabbed 4.7.1 source... I'm getting the same PKIX errors above... can't build.. should this stuff get pushed into another repo potentially if Solr will depend on it?

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Strange, the certificate is up-to-date and valid until 2017, just checked it with my browser for https://repository.cloudera.com/

Maybe your JVM is outdated and does not know the recent root certificates? Or the old cert is cached somewhere?
In my opinion, for performance reasons we should not use the cloudera repo with HTTPS? Plain HTTP should be fine to download artifacts. Checksums are checked anyway.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Ah I checked already. In 4.x branch and trunk we use http instead of https! This change to lucene/ivy-settings.xml was never backported!
Just fix this file in your checkout and then it should work without certificate errors.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
should this stuff get pushed into another repo 

See my link to the JIRA issue above about Kite moving to Maven Central.

comments.author: Mark Miller
comments.content:
This change to lucene/ivy-settings.xml was never backported!

Right - when I did it, I imagined it as just a temporary workaround - the certificates were fixed a few hours later. I'm not sure why it would remain an issue, other than the same guesses above.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Mark: It makes no real sense to downbload artifacts with HTTPS. The validity of artifacts is checked via checksums, so HTTPS just slows down for the user. The repo servers additionally support HTTPS for stuff like login (write access), but the normal user won't need https. The second problem is the set of root certificates shipped with your JVM. On Linux, the OpenJDK one is very limited depending on the distribution. Because of this we should not rely on SSL when downloading artifacts. In 4.x and trunk we no longer do this.

Once SVN is working again, I will synchronize the ivy-settings.xml file between the 3 branches. They are very different due to merges affecting order of entries and partly also different URLs.

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content: I synchronized the ivy-settings.xml accross the 3 branches (trunk, 4.x, 4.7.x).

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content: Close issue after release of 4.8.0

There seems to be some problems with repo:

<ibiblio name="releases.cloudera.com" root="http://repository.cloudera.com/content/repositories/releases" m2compatible="true" />

After adding repo http://repo.spring.io/libs-milestone, everything works ok.

My Pull Request: https://github.com/apache/lucene-solr/pull/47

comments.author: Uwe Schindler
comments.content:
Hi,

we won't fix this, as this problem is temporary (happened only this weekend). The fix on the later time-scale is to remove the repository alltogether, once kitesdk is in Maven Central

Uwe
